awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Enabling Morphology Control in Polymer Thin Films via Solvent Vapor Annealing
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract - Albert - 1554555

Among the next generation of technologies are ones aimed at designing medical diagnostic devices that are more accurate and portable; electronic devices that are faster, smaller, and capable of storing more information; and energy sources that are cleaner without sacrificing capacity or power. Polymers with tunable nano- and micro-structured morphologies can address the challenges associated with accomplishing these goals, and solvent vapor annealing (SVA) is becoming an increasingly important technique for controlling polymer morphology. The goal of this proposal is to show that thermodynamic equilibrium principles can enable a priori selection of SVA conditions to guide experiments aimed at achieving a specific self-assembled morphology in a polymer system of interest.

The proposed thermodynamic framework and high-throughput experimental methods should facilitate rapid discovery of next generation polymer materials, improve the accessibility of designer polymers, and enable morphology control in polymer films to address technology challenges in the health, energy, and environment sectors. Thermodynamic equilibrium principles will be used to enable a priori selection of SVA conditions to guide experiments aimed at achieving a specific self-assembled morphology in a polymer system of interest. The PI plans studies aimed at predicting polymer phase behavior during SVA. She will apply thermodynamic principles to describe and predict the phase behavior of block copolymers in this process. These thermodynamic equilibrium principles are proposed to enable a priori selection of SVA conditions to guide experiments aimed at achieving specific self-assembled morphologies in polymer systems. 

The aim of this project is to come up with an efficient manufacturing method for the production of tailor made polymer thin films, which could greatly benefit industry. Educationally, the proposed work should provide many opportunities for undergraduate students to carry out independent research projects and inspire some of them to pursue graduate studies. Activities carried out with the Society of Women Engineers (SWE) will contribute to increasing the representation of women in engineering undergraduate classes, doctoral programs, and leadership positions in industry, government, and academia. Specifically, undergraduate researchers enrolled for Independent Study have to develop research-related outreach workshops. The student-designed workshops will be integrated with existing outreach programs at Tulane such as the Girls in STEM at Tulane program, which targets 5th through 7th graders.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
This research project advanced our scientific understanding of how solvent vapor exposure impacts polymer properties, where "solvent" refers to a liquid that evaporates at room temperature and "polymer" refers to the types of molecules that make up things like plastics, rubbers, and adhesives. The first part of the research looked at how solvent vapor interacts with a block copolymer and can impact its nano-scale structure.  We showed that simple theories can predict how solvent molecules will distribute within the block copolymer nanostructure, which reduces the number of experiments needed to figure out how best to process these materials for emerging nanotechnologies, such as nanolithography for computer chips and ultrafiltration membranes for water purification. The second part of the research examined how solvent vapor interacts with a semi-crystalline polymer. Our work was performed with polycaprolactone, a biodegradable and bioresorbable polymer of interest for reducing the environmental impact of single-use plastic food packaging and for tissue engineering.  We showed that by exposing polycaprolactone films to different concentrations of solvent vapor, we could control how much of the crystalline structure dissolved, which then impacted how the film recrystallized when the solvent was removed. Through our experiments, we showed that the morphology of the films could be controlled by processing route without the need for small molecule additives.  Eliminating or reducing the use of additives in polymer materials has the potential to improve safety (no potentially harmful additives present that could leach out of the material) and recyclability (since different companies' use of different additives presents a challenge when trying to re-mold recycled plastics into new products) of polymer materials.

Beyond the research findings, broader impacts of this project included bi-annual K-12 outreach, development of a service-learning class for undergraduate chemical engineering majors, and exploration of ideas for more formal (classroom) education for graduate students on scientific communication.  The K-12 workshops focused on polymers in our everyday lives (specifically, hydrogels, the type of polymer used for super-absorbency of baby diapers) and were delivered through Tulane?s Girls in STEM at Tulane and Boys at Tulane in STEM programs (STEM = science, technology, engineering, and mathematics), whose target audience is students and teachers from schools whose student bodies consist mostly of students who identify as African American or other group underrepresented in STEM. The service-learning course explored partnerships with different organizations (ArcGNO: Mardi Gras bead recycling and employment of persons with disabilities; STEM Library Lab: a library of equipment teachers can check out to do hands-on demonstrations and experiments in their classes); however, the most successful was a partnership with ViaNOLAVie (a community website featuring articles related to New Orleans life, arts, and culture), in which students learned how to write about science and engineering topics for a general audience as well as the process of peer review and revision prior to publication of their articles on the website. The articles the students wrote on topics related to chemical engineering can be found by searching for the author "Big Chem-EZ' on the ViaNOLAVie website (https://www.vianolavie.org/). Finally, ideas for graduate education in scientific communication were explored through a special topics course on polymers that was offered twice; these ideas are being discussed and revisited for possible incorporation into Tulane?s chemical engineering PhD program in a format that would have broader reach by not being tied to a specific research area.   


Last Modified: 03/07/2023
Modified by: Julie Albert
